Being only able to tame Eaglets is not realistic. In Mongolia, Golden Eagles are tamed at about 4 years old, which is exactly the time when they become adults. They can only be tamed at that time, as that’s the time when they are able to hunt as well as fly. The main goal for taming Eagles has always been and cannot be for anything but hunting. Making Eagles tame-able for transportation will be labeled as animal cruelty by Mojang. If we want Eagles, we need to stick to the hunting or gift giving idea so that taming Eagles would have an appropriate and special feature. By the way, I really like the idea of hunting!
I also agree that allowing Eagles to transport you would break the purpose of the elytra and make flying too easy. Additionally, it wouldn’t make sense!

I’m totally with Eagles being neutral, and I want them to attack if attacked or if you go near their young or eggs (like polar bears). However, no mob attacks its owner in Minecraft, meaning that Eagles should be able to breed without taming them. I thought of two ways to tame them and breed them separately. First, the Eagle should be fed to enter love mode (We can decide the diet, hunts and/or gifts later). Afterwards, we can use the idea of needing a leather glove to tame them. I think that after the Eagle enters love mode, the player should select the hunting glove in his hotbar, or have it in his offhand slot, and interact with the Eagle. The Eagle should perch on the player’s arm/glove, and if it flies within a certain amount of time and brings back a hunt/gift, it is tamed. If it lands to the ground and moves away/flies but doesn’t bring anything back, it’s not. The second way is the exact same, except that it doesn’t have to enter love mode for the player to interact with it and tame it. Of course, if two Eagles enter love mode, they breed through laying in their perches or nests.

Having them hunt for you when tamed should also involve interacting using the special hunting glove, though I think an Eagle hoodie would be unnecessary. That's because all tamed mobs can be forced to sit, which is basically for preventing them to move unless attacked, so you can prevent them from hunting without hoodies if you want. We may choose that the glove loses durability as the player hunts, and there should also be a cool down before it can gift the player again. The hunting process should be done simply through a loot table. It means the Eagles just generate items and give them to you, similar to cats. It’d be better than them actually killing mobs, as the mobs they hunt might not be around, or it might not give items as valuable as what cats give, which might break the purpose of the mob. They could additionally kill certain mobs, like rabbits, on sight separate from the “hunting” mechanism that uses the interaction. This is a good compromise, because they can actually kill mobs for you when standing and also provide special hunt related loot upon interaction, just as if it had a successful hunt, regardless of mob availability. Then they should only require open space to fly around, otherwise the "hunt" fails, nothing is brought back. I think the gifts from the “hunting” process and the list of mobs they attack on sight is something Mojang would decide. I heard many great ideas, though.

I’m sure Eagles should fall into the category of mobs that follow the player when tamed. They should also be made to sit or stand by the player. That’s because they‘d have the kind of bond where they are tempted by the player feeding them and trained for a purpose in return. Same way as wolves are tempted by bones and trained to offer services to expect more, eventually loving the humans themselves for that. In Minecraft, they’re not exactly trained, but they still offer the service of attacking mobs for the player. Just like Eagles would bring gifts and loot certain mobs. After thinking, hoodies are unnecessary for the process of attacking mobs but can be an essential part for the gift giving mechanism to work. Perhaps you must put the hoodie on its eyes before you use your glove on it to make it perch and must take it of its head through your inventory for it to fly and eventually bring you something. If you’re taming it and the attempt fails, it should land to the ground after you remove the hoodie while it’s perching on the glove. Now we (or Mojang) should decide with or against the hoodie, though!
I wish people would read all comments and vote for the ones they agree with. Or comment if they have different thoughts!
and when the die they drop there eye

Sorry, but why??? I don't think you should be encouraged to kill it, you should be encouraged to tame it for the purpose of the hunting process. Many mobs, like villagers, dolphins or tame-able mobs, don't have any special or valuable drops. That's to encourage the player to use/explore this mob's abilities, rather than killing it for loot. If Eagles are gonna be tame-able, they should only drop things like feathers, because if the drops were better than the ability to tame them, everyone would kill them and there would be no point for spending time to tame them. It's a choice; you either want the mob for its special loot, or for what it can provide for you (trades, defense, gifts, etc...)

Besides, I wouldn't like Eagles to be a mob player's are meant to hunt. First, Mojang would say that this promotes animal cruelty, because Eagles are endangered, and are not an animal we need to hunt to survive. Second, hunting is what they're used for in real life, which requires taming them. Last, their style of "hunting" would also be a quirky new feature in Minecraft; they could give rather valuable loot if they use a loot table. Like when tamed cats give gifts after sleeping with the player, as mentioned above. Examples of loot: Spider eyes, string, rabbit products (meat, hide and feet), fish, and perhaps emeralds, rarely. They could also be able to attack mobs like phantoms, but only if they attack the player first.

I love the idea of birds of prey in general including owls.  What if though as some people mentioned below you are encouraged to breed them.  Maybe there is a reward for successfully breeding and getting the endangered bird of choice to survive for a certain amount of days.  Maybe you could get something like an eagle claw / feather as a reward which together can be crafted into a magical orb that can offer a new type of potion.  But you need to have several of each to encourage the breeding program.  You need to work for it.  I like the additional idea of using them for hunting, and if the player is attacked they support you, but remaining neutral until they are tamed.  Someone described that quite well.  I don't like the idea of flying, although technically I do, I think that would remove reasons for going to the end.  Or an Eagle feather that is only obtainable from breeding rather than killing could add power to the elytra - meaning you can travel about twice as far before needing a firework.

I really like the idea of a drop upon breeding. This will really give a reason to breed these mobs, and I think an Eagle Feather is a good idea, regardless of the use we decide on. I also think that a good use for an Eagle Feather would be crafting arrows that are able to shoot longer distances and reach higher altitudes (not stronger ones). Maybe you could even upgrade existing arrows in a fletching table through that feather! Potion making is also a good idea.

Please don't describe the Phantom (or anything so trivial as a video game mob) using words like "hate" or "dumb". It's pretty childish of you. They are very strong words that have their use in specific situations, and this is not one of them.

Now to address your concerns.

1) Not wanting to have Phantoms added to the game because you don't like them is a perfectly reasonable opinion. However, you're going to have to do more than call them "annoying" to convince anyone that your opinion is correct. Tell us why they shouldn't be added. Are they imbalanced to the point that no adjustments will save them? If so, how?

2) Factions servers will have no problem dealing with Phantoms if they don't want them around, so your other point is moot. There are command-based ways to get rid of them.

3) Even if you have Phantoms spawn on you, in a faction world or your own survival world, you could always just stay indoors or go mining to avoid them entirely. So there are options available besides sleeping or fighting them.

I think phantoms are already pretty fairly balanced.  They only attack when you're out in the open, so you can still stay safe from them even if you aren't able to sleep.  And MacchuPicchu is right that if they cause problems on big servers, those servers already have ways to fix it.

And with the phantoms a thing, people are more likely to agree to sleep at night.

At least see how it's playing out before deciding it's a massive problem.
They are great mobs why should they get removed ?

Here's my take, sure keep them in but fix the little annoyances that bug people. Examples:

Hitbox- the phantom hitbox is similar to that of a bat or baby zombie where only the body can be targeted while it consists of mostly wings. I suggest rather making the hitbox larger or make them move more predictable cause as is it's an absolute pain to use anything other than a bow. 

Spawning range- with other mobs there's a minimum range they can spawn away from a player but I have them spawn within 10 blocks of me almost always. So make them spawn at the same minimum distance as all the other hostile mobs. 

Noise- they are very quiet, if not the quietest hostile mob(excluding creepers) so before they attack they should have a sound like a screech or something like the creeper has a fissile. 

Phantoms are a very unique mob and I'd like to see them optimized for maximum intricacy for minimum stress, as is however I believe they need some tweaking.

What follows is my original writing. After reading other comment? Yes. Hate is exactly the word that is needed here. A community voted for it and a programmer sat down and CREATED a mob that is annoying and takes the fun out of this game? Remove them.

And don't get me wrong, at first I dealt with them. But when 8 of them spawned (I know the cap is 6, they just kept spawning and coming at me once I destroyed one) and proceeded to kill me far from home. Now (luckily) I retrieved my stuff but lost 32 levels of experience because I was essentially Phantom spammed/zerged. Don't fix the spawn cap. They're annoying, but they aren't really any more annoying than any other mob.

Phantoms after spawning will only attack players within the area they spawned at. So that means if you're on the move, you don't have to worry about phantoms at all, and neither does anyone else who wasn't close to your position. Any other mobs would be just as annoying if they spawned at you while you're build filling the place with torches doesn't prevent them from spawning. I read that just lying down on a bed will prevent them from spawning for a while, but then it won't stop them from circling overhead if an insomniac player happened to pass by (I think at this point you could blame the insomniac).

I don't think they break the game. They don't really need any major adjustments or outright removal. As of 1.13.2, they're actually very noisy, and will telegraph their synchronized dive attack.

I personally have no issue at all with the phantoms, although perhaps they could be tweaked so that lying in a bed for x amount of time (should be about the time it takes to get to sleep) is enough to prevent them spawning in, to help players on multiplayer worlds/servers. A lot of the issues people seem to have with the mob is that they are unwilling to adapt their play style to avoid the mobs. It is not hard to carry a bed around, as they are fairly cheap to make and easy to destroy and move on with. Equally having to sleep one night in every three doesn't seem like a meaningful issue at all. At the point in the game where players are trying to mob farm, most players are probably not troubled by the regular mobs, so adding in phantoms as an extra challenge is a good idea in my opinion. In fact, there are not enough flying mobs in the game, so phantoms are refreshingly unique and pose an interesting challenge to overworld players.

Given how this is going, Im going to take the time to restate some points, as well as highlighting a few issues here.

First of all, I want to deal with the comments themselves, and probably reiterate some of what MacchuPicchu96 said initially.
1) Opinions, whilst valid, are not arguments. You cannot simply say phantoms should be removed because you don't like them. Equally, you cannot say they should stay just because you love them.
2) a couple of people attacked MacchuPicchu96 because of his comment about the language used. Regardless of whether the words were 'too strong' or not, that does not affect the actual merits or issues with his arguments for why phantoms are not an issue, which those commenters neglected to address in their response.

Now, onto the actual debate.
I personally have no issues with phantoms. However, my play style is very much centres around going out at day and returning to sleep at night. Thus I don't encounter phantoms.

Nevertheless, I find that some of the issues with phantoms are trivial and more focussed on people's stubbornness. The first of these is that it limits the ability to construct massive structures. It would take at most 30 seconds to place a bed, sleep in it, then destroy it again and carry on building. And this only has to be done every third night. You don't lose any more time by sleeping; the ten minutes of night you 'skip' by sleeping has no effect on the real world. So I do not see that as an issue.

With regards to exploring, ok taking beds does change your spawn, so you have to decide whether to take beds and risk spawning miles from your base, or not taking beds and risk being killed by phantoms. As this is not my play style, I am not the most qualified to judge, but it seems to me that the risk of death by phantoms is greater than the risk of dying by any other means and spawning miles away.

About the noise, if it is indeed an issue then it should be lowered, but there is probably a reason it is so loud. Again, never having encountered phantoms, I don't know.

People complaining about the difficulties to XP farming, phantoms also drop XP. So just kill the phantoms instead. Or, if that is too difficult for you, sleep every third night. You don't lose XP by sleeping, and mobs will still spawn the next night. Equally, killing mobs is not the only activity that yields XP, though it is probably the most reliable method.

I am not a server player so I will not address the issues concerning phantoms on servers.

Before everyone who disagrees with me attacks me for my different opinion, I have done my best to clearly signpost what is fact and what is my opinion. If you wish to comment your disagreement, please focus on my arguments, as that is actually relevant to the debate and is constructive, rather than just giving me abuse for not thinking the same way as you. Apologies for the multiple part comment, but I had to circumnavigate the character limit.

Phantoms are an interesting mob, and I think they should be included. However, they don't follow the rules of Minecraft mobs.

Certain mobs spawn and are immediately hostile. I have some control of whether or not they spawn in my immediate vicinity by controlling the light level. This gives me the ability to prevent them from attacking because they are to far away to be aggro-ed.

This is not true with Phantoms. When they spawn, they are immediately hostile, I have no ability to prevent them from spawning, and when they spawn they are always close enough to be aggro-ed.

I can't tell if this was a deliberate break from the game mechanics or if it was an accident. I suspect it may have been the latter.

Still, I don't want them removed. So, here is my solution:

--Phantoms will not enter an area that is sufficiently lit, unless aggro-ed (such as with the Enderman). Everything else stays the same.--

This allows traditional base building at night without bed gimmicks, and keeps the danger of night exploration. It also fits the game lore of Phantoms disappearing at daybreak.

I really hate Phantoms.

I have been playing Minecraft since the Alpha days, which feels like a century ago. Almost every single update since the early times has been a general net positive for me. I enjoy the large number of mobs, the more realistic biome "feel" of generated lands, and I'm excited for the Cave updates that are going to functionally change how Minecraft caves work.

However, I HATE PHANTOMS.

Never once have I ever, in my history of playing the game, wished for a mob like that. I never wanted a mob that actively punished the player for spending "too much time above ground and not sleeping." It deeply discourages players from long-term exploration and harshly handicaps the ability to travel across the world map without the need for a resting spot.

Sure you can fight your way through the night, the Zombies, the Skeletons, the Witches, and the Creepers (etc.)

But what do you do when Phantoms spawn? Nothing. You die. Only relatively late-game players stand a chance of fighting back, otherwise you have to force yourself underground or into an enclosed space, which really sucks the fun out of the whole Minecraft experience.

Over 2 years later, Phantoms are one of the most hated mobs in the game.

Why? When they spawn, they spawn in swarms. If you kill the entire swarm, another swarm spawns, sometimes before you can even kill the entire swarm, leading to having 4 of the dive bombing pieces of crap chasing you down.

On a server this is doubly annoying. Why? Because the easiest way to get rid of them in solo, sleeping, is NOT always an option depending on the server.

Additionally, their AI is genuinely dumb, they repeatedly get stuck in walls, under roofs, etc. It feels like whomever designed them only put in half of the effort they should have.

Lastly, for such an annoying hazard, they happen far, FAR too often, and unlike other mobs who don't spawn near light sources, there's no real way to stop them from spawning over an area besides building unsightly glass domes. There's no automated turrets to shoot at them, there's no block you can put on a pedestal to ward them off, there's no armor enchantments that drive them away, etc. Honestly, as I type this, I'm looking up a server side mod to just outright remove them from the game.

The game felt far, far better before these nuisances were introduced with literally zero way to handle them other than to sleep, go inside, or stare at the sky with a bow/sword all night. 

10/10 Idiotic Design

The are not tough once you earn a Power V Infinity Bow (lol), but because of their extreme spawn rate, they really just add an annoyance to the game, which is a tremendous shame.  Anything that is just not necessary or is annoying to a major part of the game, should be seriously looked at and fixed.

My suggestion is keep it the same, but once you kill off the initial spawn wave, they cannot spawn again until the next night cycle.  This way, you still have to deal with them if they spawn, but the are not designed to just be annoying and limit your ability to explore at night or build at night if you want to...

I still like the mob, cool design, love to see more recipes or options to make them even more valuable.  But the current condition takes away from a great game, which is a shame.

So, quite a few comments are telling people that this CAN be turned off, but the method of doing so isn't always available. In order to disable phantoms you need to have cheats enabled and then type the following:

/gamerule doInsomnia false

This does disable phantom generation for both single player maps and servers. However, again, it requires that cheats be enabled. If the world was created without cheats it would require an external program to turn them back on.

This means that the option of disabling phantoms requires the use of cheats or mods, whereas disabling all mobs simply requires changing to peaceful mode. That just doesn't make sense to me. This should be an option within the GUI of single player or a server setting.

Other comments would commonly say that we don't have to sleep - just touch a bed - and, well, this is true. You can carry a bed around and every 3 nights just drop it somewhere, get in, then get out, and continue. Kind of tedious though, and for skyblock maps it's usually a long while because I have the ability to make a bed.

That just leaves death. The thing is though one shouldn't be required to die just to make a mob go away. 

Now, others have pointed out very good alternatives to removing the phantom outright, and I'd have to agree with them. Making it spawn in some other way, or not spawning in the light, would help. They can already spawn during the day if during a thunderstorm and at light level of 7 or less, so tie them to that light level.

Here are my points:
Volume: The Phantom is far too loud and stresses me out whenever I’m just trying to play. Minecraft isn’t supposed to be a stressful game (as far as I know) and this is really out of place.
Time to kill: Phantoms take way too long to kill if you don’t have a really strong weapon, and if you miss because the hitbox only consists of the head. This makes it unnecessarily hard for minimum rewards.
Rewards: For defeating these somewhat difficult mobs, you get minimal experience and an item that only does two things, one of which was repairing the Elytra, which Leather used to do. This takes away from Leather’s uses, as Leather isn’t good for very many things. The other is Slow Falling Potions but most people forget those exist anyway.
Preventing creativity:
Phantoms always come and attack you whenever you’re trying to build or adventure at night. This forces you to go to sleep, which is counterproductive and I’d much rather be building than wasting time sleeping.
Damage: the amount of damage they deal is very unbalanced for a mob that attacks in packs.
Those are the reason the Phantom is a bad gameplay mechanic.

Ants: can have a colony in grass and dirt blocks ranging from 1x1 blocks to 5x5 blocks. queen ants usually hide out unless it is time for their nuptial flight (as you said, around every 5-10 days) they lay eggs, and if you happen to encounter one you can catch it in a jar, but the jar has durability that goes down the longer you keep the ant in the jar. If durability reaches 0, the queen ant dies. if you have an ant farm, ants will very rarely yield items (commonly items like dirt, but more rarely they may yield a low level metal such as a piece of iron ore), the chances of this increasing with the amount of ants in the farm (increases gradually). Worker ants behavior depend on the species. Colonies spawn with 1-5 workers, similar to beehives.

Carpenter Ant: will pick items that are considered food items (rotten flesh, raw meats, apples, etc.) and deliver it to their queen. they are Neutral unless you attack one or break one of their colony blocks (see paragraph 1). they are very weak. Other than this they are quite boring.

Fire Ant: Super aggressive, will attack anything and they do more damage than most other ants. They kill animals and bring the drops back to their colony.

Army Ant: Super aggressive and do not have nests. Instead, they raid other nests and kill all the ants, and steal their eggs to eat. They also attack everything else, like fire ants, but do slightly more damage.

 

Sugar Ant: Neutral mobs that only attack you if you break one of their colony blocks, and they run away if you hit them. They pick up fruit and sugar and are extremely weak.

 

Oh yeah, and if ants from different colonies meet, they will fight.

I like the idea of sloths, but I think that they should be added differently. They spawn in subareas of jungles where it rains a lot (rainforests). They climb along trees and eat leaves. If you break a rainforest leaf, there is a chance it will give you a cecropia leaf that can breed sloths. When breeded, their baby crawls on a parent's back until it grows up. They are very slow, and they can either be three-toed or two-toed. They are neutral mobs that will only attack you if you punch it. They should have 10-15 health points. If you can put a lead on a baby sloth or attract it with a cecropia leaf before it can crawl onto it's parent's back, it will be tamed, and will crawl along the floor slowly, following you. If it catches up, it will climb on your back and hug you. Sloths will only drop leaves. The cecropia leaf is poisonous, but can make a potion of slowness. When a tamed baby sloth grows up, it will still be tamed. You can "sit" a tamed sloth, or make it fall asleep. When you do so, it will climb onto a wall if it is two or less blocks away from it. They can be two-toed or three-toed sloths. When climbing a tree, there is a 50% chance the sloth will fall asleep. They are bad fighters, and if they are attacked, they will hit you, but it only does one heart. Like llamas, they will hit you as many times as you hit them. If a sloth sees you kill a baby sloth, it will attack until you are dead and will do two hearts rather than one.
